post.title: US 20yr Treasury Bond ETF
post.body:
This is the 20yr US Treasury Bond ETF (TLT) weekly chat.

post.title: Bond Market
post.body:
FT reported that [Bill Gross](https://www.ft.com/content/8febc589-84f7-3d61-87a5-d3e9c3343578) has gone "short" on bond market. In other words, he is expecting the bond market to plunge.

On the weekly chart, the 20 year yield has made a higher high in late 2017 in comparison to the lower high at the first half of 2016\. One need to watch this signal and see how far bond value can go down, or yield can go higher.

Some of the bond charts will follow.

post.body:

post.title: Law and Sin
post.body: Romans 7:12-13English Standard Version (ESV) 12 So the law is holy, and the commandment is holy and righteous and good. 13 Did that which is good, then, bring death to me? By no means! It was sin, producing death in me through what is good, in order that sin might be shown to be sin, and through the commandment might become sinful beyond measure.

post.title: Running zeronet on a VPS - deployment
post.body:
In [this article](https://steemit.com/zeronet/@pztrn/installing-and-moving-zeronet-to-debian-jessie-with-autostarting-in-screen), the author suggested to use _screen_ to keep _zeronet_ running. I don't think using _screen_ is the most elegant approach. There is another hurdle, unless _rc-local.service_ is enabled under systemd, `/etc/rc.local` will not have any effect during the system startup, at least for Debian Stretch.

Since most modern linux distro has switched to utilize _systemd_, it makes sense to put _zeronet_ under the _systemd_ management.

Here is the service stanza file for zeronet that I used in my deployment, you should save it as `/etc/systemd/system/zeronet.service`.

```
[Unit]
Description=Decentralized websites using Bitcoin crypto and the BitTorrent network
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=zeronet
Group=zeronet
WorkingDirectory=/opt/zeronet
ExecStart=/usr/bin/env python2 zeronet.py --config_file /etc/zeronet.conf
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

Here is the zeronet config file (`/etc/zeronet.conf`):

```
[global]
data_dir = /var/lib/zeronet
log_dir = /var/log/zeronet

ui_ip = 127.0.0.1
```

Run the following commands and you now have a running _zeronet_ on your VPS:

```
systemctl enable zeronet.service
systemctl start zeronet.service
```

In the next installment, I am going to show you how to put _zeronet_ behind _Tor_ network to achieve anonymity.

post.title: Running zeronet on a VPS -- preparation
post.body:
I used a KVM VPS as the test bed for deployment. I am running the latest debian release _Stretch_.

Arch Linux has made a [zeronet package](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/zeronet/) release. Following their convention, I will put all zeronet data under _/var/lib/zeronet_, and logs under _/var/log/zeronet_. The bulk zeronet itself will be placed under _/opt/zeronet_.

First, we will create a user '_zeronet_' as the owner of the zeronet process and data.

```
sudo useradd -r -s /bin/false zeronet
```

Second, we will checkout the latest zeronet from the github repo.

```
cd /opt
git clone https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet.git zeronet
```

Third, make sure relavent directories have the proper ownership and permission.

```
chown -R zeronet:zeronet /var/lib/zeronet /var/log/zeronet /opt/zeronet
```

This concludes the preparation work.

post.title: Running zeronet on a VPS
post.body: I have successfully moved my zeronet installation from windows to a KVM vps. Details will follow.
